close_symbols: struct lfs_file_config (members: attr_count, attrs[].type, attrs[].size, attrs[].buffer, buffer)
struct lfs_file_t (members: cfg, flags, cache.buffer, cache.size, cache.block, cache.off, id, m, ctz, type)
explanation:
Why each symbol is required for checking MISRA: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant

- LFS_READONLY: Preprocessor flag; presence/absence removes or enables whole branches and their controlling expressions. Need to know which code is actually compiled to see which conditional expressions exist.

- LFS_O_WRONLY, LFS_O_RDONLY, LFS_O_CREAT, LFS_O_EXCL, LFS_O_TRUNC: File-open flag macros used in bitmask comparisons (e.g. (flags & LFS_O_WRONLY) == LFS_O_WRONLY). Their numeric definitions are needed to decide if those comparisons can ever be non-varying (e.g. if flags is constrained elsewhere or macros equal 0/constant).

- LFS_ERR_NOENT, LFS_ERR_NOSPC, LFS_ERR_NAMETOOLONG, LFS_ERR_NOTDIR, LFS_ERR_EXIST, LFS_ERR_ISDIR, LFS_ERR_NOMEM: Error-code macros used in comparisons and as control-flow sentinels. Knowing their values and semantics is required to determine whether tag/error comparisons are meaningful or effectively constant in compiled code paths.

- LFS_MKTAG, LFS_TYPE_REG, LFS_TYPE_INLINESTRUCT, LFS_TYPE_STRUCT, LFS_TYPE_USERATTR, LFS_BLOCK_INLINE: Tag construction and type constants are used in tag comparisons (via lfs_tag_type3/tag_size) and to decide code paths (inline file handling). Their definitions are needed to reason whether tag-related tests (e.g. lfs_tag_type3(tag) == LFS_TYPE_INLINESTRUCT) are potentially invariant or depend on runtime data.

- struct lfs_file_config and its members (attr_count, attrs[].type, attrs[].size, attrs[].buffer, buffer): The for-loop controlling expression i < file->cfg->attr_count and subsequent per-attribute checks rely on these members. To decide if the loop condition is invariant (always false/true) we must know whether attr_count is a compile-time constant or may vary at runtime and how attrs[] fields affect inner conditionals.

- struct lfs_t members name_max, attr_max, cfg->cache_size: These members are used in name-length checks, attribute size checks, and malloc size. Their values affect branch decisions (e.g. namelen > name_max) and therefore are required to determine if those conditionals are invariant.

- struct lfs_file_t members used (cfg, flags, cache.buffer, cache.size, cache.block, cache.off, id, m, ctz, type): The controlling expressions read file->cfg, file->flags, and cache pointer tests. Knowing whether these members can be treated as compile-time constants or are runtime-dependent is necessary to decide invariance.

- lfs_path_islast, lfs_path_isdir, lfs_path_namelen: These functions are called inside conditional expressions (directly or indirectly). Their semantics/return domains determine whether expressions using them (e.g. tag == LFS_ERR_NOENT && lfs_path_islast(path)) can be invariant.

- lfs_tag_type3, lfs_tag_size: These routines/macros extract type/size from tag values; they are used directly in controlling ifs (e.g. lfs_tag_type3(tag) != LFS_TYPE_REG and == LFS_TYPE_INLINESTRUCT). Their definitions are needed to determine whether those checks can be invariant for possible tag values.

- lfs_dir_find, lfs_dir_get: These functions compute the tag value (and thus drive many later conditionals). Understanding their possible return value ranges and error semantics is necessary to decide whether downstream tag/error comparisons in controlling expressions are potentially invariant.

In short: to determine whether any controlling expression in lfs_file_opencfg_ is effectively invariant you must know the compile-time configuration (LFS_READONLY), the numeric definitions of flag and error macros, the tag construction/type macros, the shapes and possible values of configuration structs (lfs_file_config, lfs_t, lfs_file_t), and the semantics/return domains of the helper functions used by those controlling expressions (lfs_path_*, lfs_tag_*, lfs_dir_*). Without these symbols you cannot conclude whether the tested expressions are constant/invariant or depend on runtime state.
